quoteFirst: Kingsford had retired to rest, at
quoteTime: about nine o'clock in the evening
title: Harper's New Monthly Magazine, Vol III, No 13, 1851
author: Various

quoteFirst: [2676] _i.e._ riding light and fast. The distance done between Ādampūr and Āgra was some 157 miles, the time was from 12 a.m. on Tuesday morning to
quoteLast: of Thursday. This exploit serves to show that three years of continuous activity in the plains of Hindūstān had not destroyed Bābur's capacity for sustained effort, spite of several attacks of (malarial?) fever.
title: The Bābur-nāma in English (Memoirs of Bābur)
author: Babur, Emperor of Hindustan, 1483-1530; Beveridge, Annette Susannah, 1842-1929 [Translator]

quoteLast: Admiral Koltchak called at my headquarters. The following gentlemen were present to receive him: Lieutenant-Colonel J.F. Neilson, Captain Stephani, Colonel R. Frank (Russian Army), and Mr.
title: With the "Die-Hards" in Siberia
author: Ward, John, 1866-1934

quoteLast: the Interpreter, one of the officers, and I returned to the trenches in a motor-car. The officers in the trenches did not want to let me go.
title: With the Indians in France
author: Willcocks, James, Sir, 1857-1926

quoteFirst: About midnight of the 28th, the picket line near the river on the southwest was driven in, and could not be re-established by the brigade which furnished it. The line in front of Fort Sanders had also been assailed and taken by the enemy, and
quoteTime: about nine o’clock in the evening
quoteLast: an order was sent to take the regiment out of the lines and place it in the immediate rear of the fort for special duty; Major Chipman had command. A little later in the evening, Companies A, C, D, and K were detached, and ordered to our lines near the river, where the enemy had a few hours before captured our rifle-pits.
title:
The History of the Twenty-ninth Regiment of Massachusetts Volunteer Infantry
in the Late War of the Rebellion
author: Osborne, William H.

quoteFirst: Together these battalions at last made some progress, but were stopped some three hundred yards in front of a nullah which was strongly held; the Gurkhas attacked on the Buffs’ right, but were also stopped, and an attempted flanking movement was of no avail. However,
quoteLast: patrols which had gone out as soon as it was dark reported that the enemy had evacuated the place and the nullah was at once occupied. The Buffs’ casualties on this day were twelve men killed and Lieut.
title: Historical records of the Buffs, East Kent Regiment (3rd Foot)
author: Moody, R. S. H. (Richard Stanley Hawks), 1854-1930; Alexander, Herbert, 1874-1946 [Artist]; Butler, Elizabeth (Elizabeth Southerden Thompson), 1846-1933 [Artist]; Paget, Arthur, 1851-1928 [Author of introduction, etc.]

quoteFirst: Rochester was by her informed, that Miss Hobart and her new favourite designed,
quoteTime: about nine o'clock in the evening
quoteLast: to walk in the Mall, in the Park; that they were to change clothes with each other, to put on scarfs, and wear black-masks: she added, that Miss Hobart had strongly opposed this project, but that she was obliged to give way at last, Miss Temple having resolved to indulge her fancy.
title: The Memoirs of Count Grammont — Volume 06
author: Hamilton, Anthony, Count, 1646?-1720; Scott, Walter, 1771-1832 [Editor]

quoteFirst: As the fellow got more and more intolerable, and as upon May 27 at
quoteLast: , he disturbed the quiet of the entire hospital by a severe paroxysm of scolding, he was placed in a single room in the psychiatric department. He was placed in bed, cut off from all communication with others, and forced to carry out his exercises.
title: Shell-shock and other neuropsychiatric problems
author: Southard, Elmer Ernest, 1876-1920

quoteFirst: At the Y. M. C. A.
title: At Plattsburg
author: French, Allen, 1870-1946

quoteFirst: All wagons, ambulances, and surplus artillery-carriages were sent to the rear before night and the troops were held in readiness to move at a moment's notice.  The orders to withdraw reached Thomas about six o'clock P.M., and the movement commenced
title: The Army of the Cumberland
author: Cist, Henry Martyn, 1839-1902
